I don't seek fame" for myself in a Kardashian sense...but I want my ideas to be famous. Is that unreasonable? I don't think so. If you are truly convicted in your ideas & values, and want to spread them, then you want your ideas to become famous. I don't think that's shameful."

The first time I hit 1,000 visitors/day (on my first website to warn of the U.S. housing bubble in 2005), it was an incredible rush. It got my gears turning - if I can hit 1,000/day, why not 10,000?, and so on." This was a skill I HAD to have."

I've always been fascinated by the power of media & the ability to reach large numbers of people. I've always been an opinionated person and (before I tapped into media), I was frustrated that I had no way to spread my ideas. Hence why I delved into web marketing & PR.
Thank you!

For me, graduating into the financial crisis of 2008 was like taking a compass and shaking it up - I was completely turned around. It took a several years to get back on track and figure out what I was truly meant to do. Hey, I'm only 32 - it's still fairly early in the game.

The same web marketing & branding skills that I used to make a nice living are what allowed me to spread my message as an anti-bubble activist. It was a great career in and of itself, but my passion has always been producing content and applying these ideas to wealth management.

For the last several years, I've made a living as a web marketing, PR, and branding professional. I did this in addition to running my media presence. I stayed away from mainstream Wall St. due to my skepticism of the direction they were heading, the risk of another crisis, etc.

Because the online media world is so competitive (partly b/c there are little barriers to entry), it's difficult to put together a business model where you can make a good living by producing content. It took me several years to come up with a good arrangement to make it happen.

Now that I'm starting full-time with Clarity Financial, @ LanceRoberts, and the rest of the team, I'm going to be producing original content once again. I'm really looking forward to that. Thank you for sticking with me during the phase where I was mostly aggregating content.

Successful trading requires you to short a bubble just before it pops. Bubble warning, however, is all about early detection.
Bubble warning and successful trading are two very different disciplines that require very different approaches. I am able to separate them.

Perma-bears" have a poor reputation because they are fighting the trend, so they always lose. That's not me at all:http://www.forbes.com/sites/jessecolombo/2015/01/31/5-misconceptions-about-economic-bubbles-and-people-who-warn-about-them/ …"

Bubbles need to be warned about as early as possible, however, that is not a signal to immediately short: http://www.forbes.com/sites/jessecolombo/2015/01/31/5-misconceptions-about-economic-bubbles-and-people-who-warn-about-them/ …

From a trading perspective, I believe in trading with the trend. That means no shorting as a bubble is inflating:http://www.forbes.com/sites/jessecolombo/2015/01/31/5-misconceptions-about-economic-bubbles-and-people-who-warn-about-them/ …

Pennant patterns typically break-out in the same direction as the trend that led to the pattern, which is why it's a continuation" pattern."
When volume and news picks up again, the market often breaks out from the pennant pattern (it's typically a continuation pattern).
Pennant patterns often form during low-volume, light news periods such as the past week's holiday trading.

To clarify, I am not anti-speculation(or); I'm pro-free markets. I'm against central banks' role in creating these speculative bubbles.
In this bubbly Speculation Era, very little of today's prices (housing, energy, etc.) are driven by true organic" supply and demand."

Just how they created an oil bubble in 2008 (http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/blogs/taibblog/wikileaks-cables-show-speculators-behind-oil-bubble-20110526 …), they did it again for the past 5 years, which is driving shale energy.

@ maxkeiser @ KeiserReport Thank you - I'll send you a message shortly.
When central banks print money, all sorts of spurious growth booms/bubbles start popping up and many of them look legitimate on the surface.
I'm all for free enterprise and oil exploration, so my angle of skepticism here is related to the risk of a bubble in shale energy.
Basically, the Fed fueled another speculative bubble in oil over the past 5 years, which then started up the shale energy boom/bubble.

The Fed & bubbles are a major reason for our high oil prices: http://www.forbes.com/sites/jessecolombo/2014/06/09/9-reasons-why-oil-prices-may-be-headed-for-a-bust/ … Without those prices there would be no shale boom.
Many Americans think the shale energy boom is completely legitimate, but they don't know the shenanigans that's going on behind the scenes.
The record low interest rates that I constantly rail against are a major enabler of the debt-driven shale energy bubble.

I think more like a brand mgr. or CEO than an accountant. Accountants only see Dollars & Cents, but the former understand intangible wealth.
If there was an abundance of high-paying careers, then sure, you'd be better off keeping a low profile...but that simply isn't reality now.
I hear many people say, I wouldn't want to be famous!" My response: Do you have the luxury of turning away other forms of capital now?"
But the avg. person is so fixated on cold hard cash that they're unaware of other forms of capital, esp. if it's intangible like social cap.
Once you are wealthy" in social capital terms, you can then convert that into financial wealth. It's much harder to go straight for $ now."
Unlike financial capital, it is easier to amass large amounts of social capital now than it ever was thanks to the internet/social media.
Fame is just having an abundance of social capital...and social capital is easier to gain than financial capital in these depressed times.
Many people think that fame is something that just falls into your lap or you're born with...wrong. It takes hard work, but can be done.
Becoming famous for something is one survival strategy in these times, as funny as it sounds to most people. It's not as crazy as it sounds.
I've been very conscious of this fact, and have invested heavily in building my own unique brand. This is my fight against commoditization.
You don't want to be a commodity employee w/similar skills as many others - you need a very unique niche and brand.
The key to career survival going forward is to have a job that is e-commerce and automation proof/resistant...ie. high valued-added careers.
